001package imagingbook.lib.util.resource;
002
003import java.io.File;
004import java.io.IOException;
005import java.io.InputStream;
006import java.net.URI;
007import java.net.URISyntaxException;
008import java.net.URL;
009import java.nio.file.FileSystem;
010import java.nio.file.FileSystemNotFoundException;
011import java.nio.file.FileSystems;
012import java.nio.file.Files;
013import java.nio.file.Path;
014import java.nio.file.Paths;
015import java.util.ArrayList;
016import java.util.Arrays;
017import java.util.Collections;
018import java.util.Iterator;
019import java.util.List;
020import java.util.Map;
021import java.util.Objects;
022import java.util.stream.Stream;
023
024import ij.ImagePlus;
025import ij.io.Opener;
026import imagingbook.lib.util.FileUtils;
027
028/**
029 * <p>Access to Java resources is not trivial and there are quite a few pitfalls
030 * to avoid. The aim of this class is to simplify access to resources contained in
031 * the local file system or inside JAR files.</p>
032 * 
033 * <p>In ordinary Java, resources can be located relative to any class in the package hierarchy.
034 * Resources are found by their relative path and may be placed in nested sub-directories.
035 * This is error-prone since there is no way at compile time to ascertain that a required
036 * resource actually exists. If a resource does not exists this will cause a run-time error.
037 * The goal of this setup is to reduce this potential danger by a few restrictions:</p>
038 * 
039 * <ul>
040 * <li>A "resource location" (RL) is a flat directory (i.e., all resources are at the same level, 
041 *              no resources in sub-directories).</li>
042 * <li>A RL contains the definition of a "marker class" which extends <strong>this</strong> class 
043 *              ({@link ResourceLocation}). This is to make sure that every resource location
044 *              is also a Java package known to exist at compile time.</li>
045 * <li>In principle, any legal name can be used for the marker class. We typically name such classes "RLOC" to
046 *              stand out against ordinary Java classes.</li>
047 * </ul>
048 * <p>For example, a marker class in {@code imagingbook.DATA.images.RLOC.java} would be defined as follows:</p>
049 * <pre>
050 * package imagingbook.DATA.images;
051 * public class RLOC extends ResourceLocation { }
052 * </pre>
053 * <p>Nothing else is needed to mark the associated package as a resource location.
054 * Here is an example how to access the associated resources from some other class:</p>
055 * <pre>
056 * ResourceLocation loc = new imagingbook.DATA.images.RLOC();
057 * Resource res = loc.getResource("boats.png");
058 * URI uri = res.getUri();
059 * InputStream strm = res.getStream();
060 * ... </pre>
061 * 
062 * <p>Specifically, an image can be opened (with ImageJ) as follows:
063 * <pre>
064 * Resource res = loc.getResource("boats.png");
065 * ImagePlus im = res.openAsImage();
066 * ImageProcessor ip = im.getProcessor();
067 * ...</pre>
068 * 
069 * Note that under the canonical Maven project structure, the associated file 
070 * locations (package structure) are:
071 * <pre>
072 * src/main/java/imagingbook/DATA/images/RLOC.java
073 * src/main/resources/imagingbook/DATA/images/boats.png
074 * ... (other resources)</pre>
075 * 
076 * or (if resources are used for testing only)
077 * <pre>
078 * src/test/java/imagingbook/DATA/images/RLOC.java
079 * src/test/resources/imagingbook/DATA/images/boats.png
080 * ... (other resources)</pre>
081 * 
082 * <p>
083 * Final note: To avoid marker classes showing up in the JavaDoc documentation,
084 * we use the following (internal) "convention" (currently under revision):
085 * </p>
086 * <ul>
087 * <li>All root resource packages/directories are named {@code DATA} (deliberately
088 * upper-case to mark them as special packages, since Java package names are generally lower-case).</li>
089 * <li>The {@code pom.xml} file contains the following entry in the configuration
090 * of the {@code maven-javadoc-plugin}:<br>
091 * {@code <excludePackageNames>*.DATA.*</excludePackageNames>}
092 * </ul>
093 * Of course these packages could be named differently and excluded individually.
094 * 
095 * 
096 * @author WB
097 * @version 2021/07/28
098 */
099public abstract class ResourceLocation {
100        
101        private final boolean injar;
102        private final URI baseURI;
103        
104        protected ResourceLocation() {
105                this.injar = classInsideJar(this.getClass());
106                this.baseURI = this.getResourceUri("");
107        }
108        
109        private static boolean classInsideJar(Class<?> clazz) {
110                URL url = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
111                String path = url.getPath();
112                File file = new File(path);
113                return file.isFile();
114        }
115        
116        /**
117         * Determines if this class was loaded from
118         * a JAR file or from the file system.
119         * 
120         * @return true if contained in a JAR file, false otherwise
121         */
122        public final boolean insideJAR() {
123//              URL url = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
124//              return new File(url.getPath()).isFile();
125                return injar;
126        }
127        
128        public URI getUri() {
129                return baseURI;
130        }
131
132        public Path getPath() {
133                return toPath(baseURI);
134        }
135        
136        /**
137         * Finds the {@link URI} for the the specified resource.
138         * The resource may be located in the file system or inside a JAR file.
139         * To convert the result to a {@link URL} use {@link URI#toURL()}.
140         * 
141         * @param resourceName The resource's simple name (including file extension, e.g., {@code "myimage.tif"}).
142         * @return The resource's {@link URI} or {@code null} if the resource was not found
143         */
144        private URI getResourceUri(String resourceName) {
145                Objects.requireNonNull(resourceName);
146                URI uri = null;
147                if (injar) {
148                        String classPath = this.getClass().getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation().getFile();
149                        //String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', File.separatorChar);
150                        String packagePath = this.getClass().getPackage().getName().replace('.', '/');
151                        String compPath = "jar:file:" + classPath + "!/" + packagePath + "/" + resourceName;
152                        try {
153                                uri = new URI(compPath);
154                        } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
155                                throw new RuntimeException(e.toString());
156                        }       
157                }
158                else {  // regular file path
159                        try {
160                                URL url = this.getClass().getResource(resourceName);
161                                if (url != null) {
162                                        uri = url.toURI();
163                                }
164                        } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
165                                //do nothing, just return null
166                        }
167                }
168                return uri;
169        }
170        
171        /**
172         * Returns an array of all resource names in this class's immediate directory
173         * (excluding this class's .java/.class files).
174         * 
175         * @return a sorted array of names (possibly empty)
176         */
177        public String[] getResourceNames() {
178                Path path = this.getPath();
179                // with help from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1429172/how-do-i-list-the-files-inside-a-jar-file, #10
180                if (!Files.isDirectory(path)) {
181                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("path is not a directory: " + path.toString());
182                }
183                
184                List<String> nameList = new ArrayList<>();
185                try (Stream<Path> walk = Files.walk(path, 1)) {         // walk is auto-closed!
186                        final String className = this.getClass().getSimpleName();
187                        for (Iterator<Path> it = walk.iterator(); it.hasNext();) {
188                                Path p = it.next();
189                                if (Files.isRegularFile(p) && Files.isReadable(p)) {    
190                                        String name = p.getFileName().toString();
191                                        // exclude .java and .class files of THIS class
192                                        String nameOnly = FileUtils.stripFileExtension(name);
193                                        if (!nameOnly.equals(className)) {
194                                                nameList.add(name);
195                                        }
196                                }
197                        }
198                } catch (IOException e) { }
199
200                String[] sa = nameList.toArray(new String[0]);
201                Arrays.sort(sa);
202                return sa;
203        }
204        
205        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
206        
207        /**
208         * Converts an {@link URI} to a {@link Path} for objects that are either
209         * in the file system or inside a JAR file.
210         * 
211         * @param uri the specified {@link URI}
212         * @return the associated {@link Path}
213         */
214        public static Path toPath(URI uri) {
215                Path path = null;
216                String scheme = uri.getScheme();
217                switch (scheme) {
218                case "jar":     {       // resource inside JAR file
219                        FileSystem fs = null;
220                        try { // check if this FileSystem already exists 
221                                fs = FileSystems.getFileSystem(uri);
222                        } catch (FileSystemNotFoundException e) {
223                                // that's OK to happen, the file system is not created automatically
224                        }
225                        
226                        if (fs == null) {       // must not create the file system twice
227                                try {
228                                        Map<String, Object> map = Collections.emptyMap();
229                                        fs = FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, map);       // FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, Collections.<String, Object>emptyMap());
230                                } catch (IOException e) {
231                                        throw new RuntimeException(e.toString());
232                                }
233                        }
234                        
235                        String ssp = uri.getSchemeSpecificPart();
236                        int startIdx = ssp.lastIndexOf('!');
237                        String inJarPath = ssp.substring(startIdx + 1);  // in-Jar path (after the last '!')
238                        path = fs.getPath(inJarPath);
239                        break;
240                }
241                case "file": {  // resource in ordinary file system
242                        path = Paths.get(uri);
243                        break;
244                }
245                default:
246                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot handle this URI type: " + scheme);
247                }
248                return path;
249        }
250        
251//      private HashMap<String, Resource> collectResources() {
252//              final String className = this.getClass().getSimpleName();
253//              //Path[] paths = getResourcePaths(this.path);
254//              //Path[] paths = getResourcePaths(this.getPath());
255//              Path[] paths = getResourcePaths();
256//              HashMap<String, Resource> resTable = new HashMap<>();
257//              for (Path p : paths) {
258//                      String n = p.getFileName().toString();
259//                      // exclude .java and .class files of THIS class
260//                      String nameOnly = FileUtils.stripFileExtension(n);
261//                      if (!nameOnly.equals(className)) {
262//                              resTable.put(n, new Resource(n, p));
263//                      }
264//              }
265//              return resTable;
266//      }
267        
268        // --- these are the only methods exposed: -----
269        
270        public Resource getResource(String resourceName) {
271                URI uri = getResourceUri(resourceName);
272                return (uri == null) ? null : new Resource(resourceName, uri);
273        }
274
275
276//      public Resource[] getResources() {
277//              return this.resources.toArray(new Resource[0]);
278//              return this.resourceMap.values().toArray(new Resource[0]);
279//      }
280        
281        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
282
283        /**
284         * Instances of this class represent individual resources contained in
285         * a particular {@link ResourceLocation}.
286         * This is a non-static class, since {@link Resource} instances can only
287         * exist in the context of a {@link ResourceLocation}.
288         */
289        public class Resource {
290
291                private final String name;
292                private final URI uri;
293
294                private Resource(String name, URI uri) {
295                        this.name = name;
296                        this.uri = toPath(uri).toUri(); // trick to get absolute URIs like "jar:file:///D:/..."
297                }
298
299                /**
300                 * Returns the name of this resource.
301                 * @return the name of this resource
302                 */
303                public String getName() {
304                        return name;
305                }
306
307                /**
308                 * Returns the {@link Path} to the associated resource object.
309                 * @return the resource's {@link Path} 
310                 */
311                public Path getPath() {
312                        return toPath(uri);
313                }
314
315                /**
316                 * Returns the {@link URI} for the associated resource object.
317                 * @return the resource's {@link URI} 
318                 */
319                public URI getUri() {
320                        return uri;
321                }
322
323                public ImagePlus openAsImage() {
324                        return new Opener().openImage(uri.toString());
325                }
326                
327                /**
328                 * Returns an {@link InputStream} for reading from this resource.
329                 * See also {@link Class#getResourceAsStream(String)}.
330                 * @return an {@link InputStream} for this resource
331                 */
332                public InputStream getStream() {
333                        Class<?> clazz = ResourceLocation.this.getClass();
334                        return clazz.getResourceAsStream(name);
335                }
336
337        }
338}
